title: Work Experience Review
pros: My time as an Investment Analyst at Equity Residential has been incredibly rewarding, offering numerous opportunities for professional growth and development. One of the biggest pros of the role is the learning environment. The learning curve is steep but highly rewarding, as you gain exposure to a variety of deal processes, from initial due diligence to finalizing transactions. This hands-on experience provides a deep understanding of the real estate investment landscape. A major advantage of the role is the level of deal exposure. Analysts are involved in various stages of the deal process, providing a unique opportunity to see how deals are structured and executed. This is complemented by the collaborative nature of the work, as you have the chance to interact with different teams across the company, including asset management, finance, and operations. This cross-functional collaboration is not only enriching but also gives a holistic view of how various elements contribute to successful investments. Another key benefit is the potential for growth. With the high pace of learning and the continuous exposure to new challenges, there is a lot of room for career advancement. Equity Residential fosters an environment where initiative and hard work are recognized, making it a great place for those looking to advance within the field of real estate investment.
cons: One of the main challenges of the Investment Analyst role at is prioritizing the workload, especially when you're starting out. The learning curve is steep, which can make the initial adjustment period quite intense. Balancing multiple projects, tight deadlines, and the detailed nature of the analysis required can be stressful, particularly as you work to master the various aspects of the deal processes. However, this intensity can also be seen as a part of the growth experience, as it encourages you to quickly adapt and build strong time management skills.

title: Frustration

title: Don't believe the hype!
pros: The CEO and upper echelon of the company has taken many steps to develop a healthy work environment. There is a strong push toward ownership and responsibility on the individual level. However, the concepts touted fall flat when the individual exercises them.
cons: Managers and coworkers make the climate. Without purpose, direction, and understanding it is easy to loose motivation. For maintenance professionals, the training is all "hands on" or on the computer. The computer training is from the company, but the on job training varies greatly from supervisor to supervisor. As a floating service technician, I saw the majority of properties in the DC metro area. None of them had similar standards. Most of the supervisors rely on verbal instructions over proper training. With that said, from my experience, the number one con is lack of leadership. There are plenty of bosses, but no leaders. Furthermore, there tends to be a coercive atmosphere from the management. It seems that everyone believes the customer is always right. However, it isn't exactly true. If a problem rises between the customer and employee, there is a tenancy from management to convince the employee to please the tenant. Sometimes this violates laws and policies (i.e., fair housing act and etc.). In my case, when I mentioned this grievance to management, they blew it off. Eventually, I wrote the CEO and I finally got some attention. Eventhough he deeply cared, the lower he held on of management took passed the buck onto other employees, claiming that they lacked loyalty. As others have written, it is the people that make the company. And, the DC market is deeply flawed.

title: A great learning company with some areas of opportunity
pros: Great training in place, a network of resources and coworkers, and an overall fun job. You learn great time management and are challenged with something new everyday, you never get bored! Equity is very customer facing and in my experience, the right decision was made to please the customer while also backing up their team involved in any issue. It's important to feel supported by the corporate office and Equity does this well.
cons: Moving up in the company can sometimes take longer than desired, it seems longevity is sometimes favored over the most qualified applicant. Policies and procedures put in place by the company are pretty solid, but the actual implementation varies from site to site. It would have been nice to have a space to share feedback about direct supervisors on a more regular basis.

title: Great company

cons: Working on the weekends like usual

title: great

cons: I cant think of any cons

title: Good company

title: Culture has changed for the worse. Senior leaders ignore employee feedback but pretend to care about engagement.
pros: Formerly cared about culture and employees

title: Terrible Commission Structure, Great Autonomy
pros: - If lucky, you may get a property with a great manager. Most places do not, but I did - You learn to master CRM - You can hone your sales abilities with custom tours - YOU can build a skill set on your own, just take on the project you desire: event planning, marketing, etc - Corporate office is responsive - Flexibility with your work schedule - Ability to create your day-to-day schedule - Commission CAN be good if your property is in the right neighborhood
cons: - Compared to other property management companies, the commission tier is terrible. You barely start seeing 4 figure commissions once you lease 10+ apartments a month - Most communities have terrible management. Managers leave early, speak down to employees - Training = online training that focuses more on software skills and less on sales. Minimal training in-person - NO opportunities to advance outside of leasing. The only way up is towards Sr. Leasing or Property Manager. Interested in accounting, marketing, or corporate affairs? Tough luck. Move to their HQ in Chicago. - Corp office allocates all funds to new communities. Older offices aren't even funded for basic things like business cards. - Culture is all dependent on community managers. - Corp office always trying to increase prices on residents who then complain to leasing agents.

title: Big business politics, along with out of touch management.
pros: In the REIT world Equity Residential looks great on a resume.

These are all examples of Management in the Orange County, California portfolio and HR in the West, I cannot speak for management on the East Coast of the United States: Equity management would rather look for outside talent when filling even basic positions, even though there are qualified candidates ready and willing to step up, this is a combination of RM/VP & HR "strategizing expert level". Equity Residential often likes to pigeonhole employees where they see fit in order to benefit the organization whether they or qualified for more or not, and stunt employees growth if it benefits their portfolio's numbers. When you realize these things are not right and you bring them to managements attention, there go to response is: "you're just not committed to your job or this company" or "you have become difficult to manage, and a lot of the managers are noticing" or they would like to remind you of the one time in the last year you were three minutes late to work because your child was ill, even though you called to inform your supervisor before business hours.

title: Equity review

title: Review of Experience as Current Employee

title: Lots of support and opportunities when you take an active role in your career.
pros: EQR provides a large support structure and one of the best things about it, is all you need to do is ask for help or reach out to get help that you need. Plenty of opportunities when you take an active role in your career development, you cannot sit back and wait for things to happen. When you do the right thing for the right reasons, it will be appreciated. Equity does a great job of coaching if you made a decision that was not the best, but they do not make you feel bad about the decision.
cons: Sometimes, the regional offices do feel quite separated and don't allow you to feel like a part of the larger market and instead isolated to your property. With being such a large company, newer employees can feel intimidated to reach out for help or questions.

title: Great place but not good pay
pros: Great place to work and great culture
cons: Not competitive pay compared to similar positions

title: No Sympathy for Property Team Members
pros: Senior management above the local VP is approachable and seems to truly care about the company culture and the teams. Regional Managers try to build great relationships with their teams and keep them motivated. Leasing consultants can be promoted to community managers with hard work and a lack of other qualified candidates. Pay is decent for many positions.
cons: There is a huge clique in the corporate office and it can be felt on the properties and during meetings. The Regional managers are not in the clique and try to keep the teams happy and motivated. Community managers often feel that they cannot do anything to make changes and are expected to salute and march. Properties are short staffed, only 1 person per 100 apartments which is not enough for resident's expectations. Employees are told to put good reviews on google, ratings websites and glass door for the company. Even the annual employee survey is rigged because the VP can pull statistics for regional portfolios and tell who is giving bad reviews. We even have had meetings about it with our Regional managers making everyone feel like it was to raise morale when it was just to blame managers for the reviews. Employees are afraid to be honest.

title: Joining this company was the biggest regret of my career.
pros: For the big names in the industry, EQR pays well to those who come with experience. They are also very transparent with their pay and how much room you have to grow your salary. Good resume and salary booster if you don't care about sticking around for too long.
cons: The culture of this company is poor. Morale of employees is very low as many feel spread too thin, burnt out, and not cared about. At times it was almost toxic how negative everybody was. The rate of employee turnover is insane! I saw other reviews describing the company as the "walmart of property management". Couldn't agree more - this company is cheap, cheap, cheap. They will cut everything they possibly can from the budget and scrutinize every dollar spent without any concern to the impact on the revenue these poor decisions can have. If you are lucky, capital projects will eventually get approved but they will drag their feet forever to get them done. I couldn't believe some of the safety hazards at my property! Support from facilities leadership is a joke. The corporate culture seemed more like some words on a poster than anything anyone actually tried to live by. Messages from Senior Leadership came across as robotic and ingenuine. They try to implement a one size fits all approach to their management style and on-site employees are not empowered to make any decisions on their own, micromanagement is an understatement.

title: No growth
pros: Weekends off for most. Easy work
cons: No growth. Small corporate side in AZ so don’t expect advancement

title: Good company
pros: Incentive housing discount for employees, programs to move up in company
cons: Hours are not flexible. Support at certain locations are scarce

title: Current Community Manager
pros: Equity truly is the best of the best. The training, employees and support your receive is amazing. Pay is good-not great but we operate in cities where the cost of living is high so it's relative. BUT we do get a housing discount, which really helps and a lot of people take advantage of. Other benefits like PTO, health insurance, 401K are pretty good. Health insurance can be really affordable if you participate in the wellness program and you should (can't complain about Amazon gift cards and cheaper premiums!) Career advancement is probably where Equity shines- they have great training programs for new employees and they've developed programs for their leasing consultants and service techs to gain the skills to be promoted. Upper management is also supportive and understanding. Leadership does take the time to listen to the concerns of the onsite team and will respond to concerns that are frequently brought up.
cons: Properties tend to be staffed thin. Like I mentioned above too, Equity operates in cities with a high cost of living, the pay is good but unless you live far from the buildings they manage, it's pretty expensive to live. Work/life balance can be difficult especially in the busy season.

title: Great place to work
pros: Company promotes work life balance
cons: Alway short staffed. We need better candidates for open positions

title: Management Needs to be more proactive
pros: Good Salary, Nice Competitive Environment! New Hire Orientation is great! Provides great info on our benefits! Also a great chance to meet upper management.
cons: Management often neglects to give you important information. Management is often not engaged with what is actually going on at the property (spending a couple of hours at the property does not give you an adequate idea of what is going on. Spend a week there and see what is really going on.) There should be more accountability for the actions of Property/General/Regional Managers as well as the HR department. There are a lot of nitty-gritty details and procedures that often get overlooked due to lack of training. The company as a whole needs more training (especially for rules and regulations in regard to files, roommate relinquishment/replacement, insurance, check posting/returned checks). These were only a few of the many things that adequate training is not provided for.

title: Depends on the property
pros: Good employee rental discount for properties
cons: No work life balance for managers

title: Everyone Shines
pros: Equity Residential is a REIT with more than 300 communities in 6 major metropolitan area. While there is always the need to perform better than before, when decisions follow the "10 Ways" including "do the right thing," superiors support and assist you. Working with fun, competitive, encouragers from the corporate office to onsite teams. Everyone is encouraged to be optimistic, question authority, test their limits, take educated risks, share knowledge, share the spotlight, all while enjoying the ride. Nerds who have a passion to grow in knowledge, skills, and career are welcome. Transparency, sharing the "why" of decisions, is a refreshing mode of operation at every level at Equity. Best practices, triumphs, struggles, as well as changes in policy and practice are frequently shared in the weekly Huddle that is a blend of onsite team catch-up and company-wide video fireside chats with corporate team members. The employee review process is a helpful, largely objective measure of successes, with input from peers and superiors.
cons: There is a repository of hundreds, if not thousands, of resources like online education, documents, shared ideas and best practices, that it is overwhelming for a new hire to muddle through.

pros: Long term employment with this company
cons: truction project manager

title: Equality in Equilibrium
pros: You get to help people, and not indirectly such as donating to starving kids, rather you get to deal with real-life problems and see them to their completion. Honestly, that is the driving force of their business model. This is the only company that I've worked for where the bottom of the company structure is the premise of the company. Ultimately this provides the ultimate job security as long as your compatent. If you ever need a confidence booster, try property management.
cons: Senior leadership is a shell of what you are as a consultant; almost like a reverse locus effect. You as the Leasing Consultant are the budding locus waiting to be sucked into a cocoon of mediocrity. Yes, they have a host of outdated knowledge, that doesn't necessarily pertain to our unique situation, but ultimately you are left to your own devices to manage problems. And, of course, they are there to pat you on the back if things go well, but vise versa to the alternative outcome. For those of the faint of hearts, heed my warning and find another career path, but if you thrive in conflict and hate mundane modernity such as I, then dive in and test your limits.

title: Good
pros: Time for work was a bit tasking
cons: Time for work was much

title: Overworked and underpaid
pros: If you live in an Equity Residential building, you get a rent discount. They have a great training program. The benefits package was decent.
cons: They expect too much of the employees at large properties. I was doing the job of two people. They also secret shop you, requiring you to say certain things and forcing your pitch. You are allowed no freedom as a salesperson to read the customer, no matter how many performance awards you've received. If you live on the property, the discount is not enough to deal with never leaving work. Fire alarm? Crazy resident? Walking your dog? You are always on duty. Only the Property Manager gets to live on site for free. The Assistant Manager deals with just as many hassles, sometimes more, but only gets 20%. Corporate pep rallies are excruciating. They made us dress up and the executives showed up in suits. It's tough to have a professional, face to face with your boss while wearing a football jersey and a boa. They seemed to like it that way.

title: Corporate Field Support
pros: - You get to work with some of the best talent in the industry. - There's usually a lot of upward movement available for property operations. - The employees are smart and good at what they do, but they also don't take themselves too seriously. They know how to laugh and be personable. - They care about work/life balance. - Upper management takes employee feedback seriously. - Decent rental discount if you live at one of the communities.
cons: - New ideas are sometimes hard to test or get off the ground due to the size of the company and how many people/ depts need to be involved in any one initiative. - There's a little bit of office politics that comes into play, as with any corporate environment. - A lot of the strategy and decision-making happens in the Chicago headquarters, so some in the field find it hard to be empowered and take ownership in their roles. - Health insurance coverage isn't great. You end up paying a good amount out-of-pocket.

title: Great benefits, but watch your back
pros: There is an amazing sense of comraderie among the property teams with people always willing to go above and beyond to help you. The benefits are bomb with a 4% 401K match, ESPP options, adoption money up to $20k and fertility treatment up to $20k too! Plus they have an awesome education and training program that will teach you all about property management.
cons: Although they talk about a work life balance they will work you to the bone. The company is proud to boast of its skeletal staffing and your constantly fighting to get money for the property. They will also low ball you on offers so make sure to negotiate negotiate negotiate!! They also suck you in with the apartment discount but they don’t tell you that you the money that you get taxed doesn’t make it worth it. Also upper management in Chicago is super all boys club with very little diversity with women or people of color. So beware of that glass ceiling.

title: Community Manager, New York City
pros: Great benefits, excellent property management software, plenty of learning opportunity, constant training, company outings.
cons: Pay is not enough for all the work they will put on you, very clicky environment, they will promote those that are "liked" by area or regional managers, not necessarily the most capable of doing a designated job, claim to be customer service oriented, very greedy company, it's all about $$$

title: Strong Focus on Culture and Inclusion
pros: There is a true feeling of togetherness and inclusion, and it is something that the entire company is focused on. The culture is promoted on a regular basis and makes Equity Residential a place that I am truly proud to work for and tell people about. Upward mobility is there for you to take if you put the work in. I started with zero experience at an entry level position and was able to promote to a Regional position within 10 years. Communication is great, and Executives often make time to hear from the 'little people', which is shown through policy shifts and system improvements that are suggested by on site teams. The company advocates for a strong feeling of work/life balance, allowing you to feel not only like you can, but that you should, disconnect from the business when you are not at work.
cons: Staffing runs a bit thin, so you are often very busy, but you have more empowerment than other companies to make decisions which helps efficiency and doesn't tie your hands in fast paced environments. Most entry level positions will require at least one weekend day, but you will always have 2 days off in a row to create a 'weekend'.

title: The worst company I have ever worked for!!!!!!!!!
pros: You get paid and their are benefits. They only contribute 5% to your 401k after a year and you aren't fully vested until you have worked for the company for 5 years when most places it's 10% and your fully vested after 3 years.
cons: Well to start off with the location I work at is dangerous has no security. Absolutely filthy and disgusting. If I try to speak up I am basically told nothing will change and that's just the way it is. They are constantly breaking labor laws. This company is a bunch of high school bullies that want to claw their way to the top and leave you out in the dust. I am not able to be specific on incidents for security purposes but if you like wondering if you will have a job, kissing up to unintelligent people, letting people use you and can't even breathe because of how under staffed you are then this is the company for you.

title: Smart, Hardworking People....
pros: I work in the corporate office in Chicago, and love working for EQR. I'm a long term employee (10+ years), and have no plans to leave. Most of the leaders are smart, hardworking, and approachable. Culture is casual, yet fast paced and keeps me interested and challenged. More junior level employees are given the chance to work on really high level work, and are recognized for their contribution. I feel that all of the corporate teams work well together, and there is a true sense of it being a "group effort". I also love that we have gotten much better at remembering what our corporate role is--ensuring that our on site staff can do their jobs well and feel supported.
cons: I sometimes wonder if there is any strategy involved with how people are paid--talking with co-workers, it seems that different rules apply to everyone. Although the vacation and paid time off is decent, my vacation is less here than it was when I was working for another larger firm headquartered in Chicago. I also feel that we are sometimes slow to adapt to technology & how today's workforce wants to work--it's gotten better in the last year, but I still feel like we lag behind comparable companies.

title: Love My Job!
pros: Equity Residential is committed to not only taking care of it's residents, but also the employees. I have been here 10 years and I still get blown away at the amount of time and attention the employees get. I truly feel valued and appreciated every day. Another bonus of working at Equity--my co-workers feel like family to me now after 10 years. I have made lifelong friends here. Also, Equity has really started recognizing successes more frequently and shares those successes in our weekly portfolio-wide meetings. I really feel like I live the "work hard, play hard" motto here at Equity.
cons: Some communities, in my opinion, are staffed a little light. I understand the save in salary but some communities could use maybe 1 more person in the office or 1 more person on the maintenance team (even if it's part-time or seasonal). I have only seen this at a couple of communities though.

title: Best Compamy During Covid Crisis
pros: This company doesn't just tell me I'm valued, they show me I'm valued. When the pandemic hit Equity wasted no time in responding at every level. Reduced work hours with no reduction in pay, logistical supply distribution at the corporate level and weekly meetings with CEO, CFO and other company leaders are just some of the actions taken by this company to ensure the safety and well being of employees and residents. These are actions, not words that send a clear message to me and and all employees while my colleagues at other companies are struggling for supplies, being asked to take their own temperatures before working without being provided the equipment to do so and still working full schedules. It is easy to tout a "we care about our employees" message but it is immensley difficult to quickly mobilize the actions I decribed that prove it. This company, my company is coming through with shining colors.
cons: Some of the administrative paperwork seems redundant and/or unnecessary.

title: Great Company that loves to see people grow.
pros: I have been an employee for three years and I must say it has been the best decision I have ever made as far as an employer. They were very up front when hiring on their expectations. I see that most people on here say they are over worked??? That I find wierd because if you just come and do your job you have no problems. If you do more than what is asked of you they reward you. If you show you are interested in moving up in the buisness they will promote. Bottom line if you work you get.... If you sit back and collect a check that's what you will get in return. All the tools are in place to help employees grow and move up the ladder.
cons: They demand a lot but it is well worth the effort , I personaly don't like the CLS that is used because it affects your bonus at years end and you don't have total control over the outcome of the number. You could be doing everything needed and others not doing whats needed and it goes against you.

title: Understaffed and Overworked Employees
pros: -Discounts on rent if you live at an Equity property. -You work with some really great people.
cons: -High Turnover: There is an unbelievable amount of turnover in the leasing offices. Upper management doesn't seem to care since they'll end up paying the new employee less than someone who's been there longer. About half the leasing consultants I started with in training left by the time I hit 6 months. -Understaffing: Even with high turnover, they do not fill positions quickly (sometimes months) which leaves an already understaffed office with very little support. I've seen them take advantage and completely burn out so many great employees to the point of quitting. -Work/Life Balance: You barely get any holidays off and most employees work weekends (even managers) -Manipulative management: Community and Regional managers know how to manipulate their employees when making decisions about their careers (transferring communities, promotions, quitting, etc.) and are always only looking out for themselves and their own careers.

title: Work Hard Play Hard
pros: Equity is a great place to work. There is a lot to learn because the company has many policies, procedures and overall structure. But once you learn everything, you know exactly what is expected of you. There are many resources at your finger tips and everyone has an open door policy. I am comfortable reaching out to Senior Leaders if needed. If you work hard, you can have a great career here. Promotional opportunities are competitive and I had to interview a few times before getting one. But I continuously worked with my Manager so that I was ready for the next opportunity.
cons: You have to work hard at Equity - this is not a company where you can do the minimum and expect maximum results. It would be nice to have more floaters to help at properties that need assistance to cover vacations, open positions, etc. That would help prevent getting a little burnt out when understaffed. The pros definitely more than outweigh the few cons!

title: Opportunity is there if you put in the work!
pros: Great rent discount. Competitive pay for people who go the extra mile. I've gotten a raise every single year but I've also stepped my game up every year and demonstrated my added value. Awesome people! I've made life long friends and really have a support network of people that I can count on. Incredible training. I feel like I'm getting paid to go to school. Equity is the best job I've ever had and will be one of the biggest reasons for my future success.
cons: It's not easy. If you're looking for an easy job, this isn't it. Dealing with people at properties is tough work and you have to pay your dues if you want to move up. We've all been there, and it will build character. A lot of people complain about work life balance. TBH I've been in my current role for 8 months and usually work closer to 6 days a week, but that's because I care about my building and enjoy the fruits of my labor. I'm not required to work that hard and in fact I was encouraged in my yearly review to take it easy and relax!

title: The corporate management is the best thing about working at Equity
pros: I have worked at properties that were short staffed, having a hard time or just needed someone to fill in. By staying committed to making each place better, you can really make the most out of working at equity. My regional manager has also had my back and makes sure I have everything I need to live this job. I have plans to move to New York and the corporate teams will be the part I miss from D.C. The most when I do
cons: We don't get the day before thanksgiving or Christmas Eve off. We do have floating holidays to use for those days but the office is still open so not everyone can request off for them. It's a great business decision because so many people have the time off from work and can tour. But it isn't so great if you have many people who came from different states and need to travel home for the holidays on the same teams.

title: Horrible
pros: No pros, all cons. Higher ups don’t care about their employees and will overwork them to the ground.
cons: All cons , horrible upper management

title: Experience started out positive and is ending with me being extremely disatisfied!
pros: Benefits, annual activities, Having a steady job, housing discount
cons: No real employee engagement endeavors, even though there is an annual employee engagement survey (such a joke). It seems as though Equity does not care if they lose their best workers, everyone is replaceable. No consideration is given to how decisions will affect employees, the only focus is the bottom line. Most people are overworked. If someone quits or gets fired, they take forever to replace that person and only if they absolutely have to. But in the meantime you will be given hell about audit compliance and metrics when you are just trying to stay afloat. Anything can change at any moment about your job requirement, compensation, job title, etc. I would suggest Equity being a last resort, or a temporary gig until you find something better.

title: Loyalty means nothing
pros: Decent commissions if you coerce the new residents to move-in by the end of the month as the 1st two leases each month are free (since its your job) and then tiered after that... but only if they move in the same month. Company does good job at trying to get you to drink the kool-aid with Be Think Play Live and other nonsensical awards given at what can only be described as high school pep rallies. Vacation and sick time are pretty decent. You get a day off to do community work that they never let you take.
cons: Managers and the higher ups in their Ivory Towers have their favorite employees. If you don't conform to their ideology then you are marked. Men don't get treated the same as women and are tasked with more... and they expect more from you. No promotion from within. New managers from outside the company. No assistant managers, only Sr. Leasing which isn't in the budget. Staffing used to be decent until they tried to get by cheap and require managers to be multistage which leaves on site leasing staff to do more than compensated for.

title: Worst job I've ever had
pros: Pay is on the low level of acceptable but benefits and company discounts were pretty good
cons: Equity will push incentives to have current employees leave positive reviews that they would not do otherwise. I had multiple female leasing agents confide in me about harassment they received from managers. Human resources has clearly never heard of the NLRB, and absolutely do not follow the law when it comes to treating and paying employees properly. At least 2 other people that I know have pursued legal action against Equity for things like unpaid wages, and I would have also but I just wanted to be done with the nightmare and never think about that place ever again. Management sleeping with other managers/vendors/residents is common. Service staff (maintenance/leasing) is held to a lower standard than management, as Equity has a "do as I say not as I do" policy. 2017 Class action lawsuit against Equity for violating state laws, and I doubt it'll be their last. They contract out labor to subs who hire/take advantage of undocumented immigrants to save costs especially in busy season. The amount of unnecessary landfill waste this company produces is staggering, we'd throw away any appliance that worked fine but had minor cracks right into the dumpster every single day.

title: Continuously evolving with their employees!
pros: When I began my journey with Equity, I never envisioned that this would be a now 7 year career. There are so many good things to say that it almost seems unbelievable for those looking in or reading this review. There is something to be said about a company that treats their employees well and I am here to shout it from the rooftops! I am so very happy with the years that I have spent learning different positions all over the Orange County Area and the company only continues to listen and evolve with the resident/employee feedback! I am a true believer that your voice will be heard, your suggestions will be considered, and your time and efforts as an employee will be recognized. I will continue to acknowledge Equity for all of their accomplishments in regard to my positive experiences (recognition, EXTRAORDINARY benefits especially maternity/paternity, career development/growth, continuous change for the best, diversity, ETC.) I am so thankful for the opportunities that I have had and the ones that will be with me for many years to come as Equity and I continue to evolve together.
cons: Property Management can be challenging at any level.

title: Forever a stockholder, but it would be hard to come back as an employee
pros: Good medical insurance, maternity/paternity leave, great place to climb the ranks if you don't have a college degree
cons: First and foremost priority is the shareholder - it's all about the bottom line. Direct manager's aren't given the ability to properly reward and recognize top employees. A top employee may not rent the most apartments, but put in the extra work and work outside their job description. Lastly, the things upper management makes you do to residents can be crazy at times. In my opinion, sometimes if the lease says something there is still room for forgiveness. When bad news has to be delivered, it is usually delivered from community/service managers, leasing consultants, or technicians (rarely at a higher level than that). In order to stick to community guidelines and avoid using trade secrets or confidential information, I won't elaborate on some of the border line unethical practices I've witnessed. Although, there are standard practices that would make it so I would never put my family or myself in an Equity Apartment.

title: Good for the experience to put on your resume.
pros: -good pay (32bj union) -union, good benefits -ok residents -Christmas money
cons: - toxic - very toxic -poor management. No managerial skills what so ever. Been in two buildings, both exactly the same. - must be a kiss up to be in good standings. - being outspoken an knowledgeable makes you the black sheep. - coworkers, gossip all day. Do anything to get you in trouble if you are not on the same page as them. -majority of coworkers were illiterate, literally. They were still praised for doin nothing - working hard won’t get you noticed, kissing up will. - if you are a porter, you will do every job in the building, an not get no credit, or even a thank you. - expect you to go above and beyond, but is never reciprocated. - will talk promotions to you everyday, but will not move you up, unless you’re kissing major up, or you are family. - ECT, ECT.

title: They Really Need To Watch Who They're Highering & Promoting For Management Or Leadership Material
pros: I love the atmosphere of the beauty of my building and the bond that you develop with your residents. They really make you feel like you are making a difference in their dailly life.
cons: There is a lot of childish behavior being displayed amongst management and their inner clicks! If your not clicked in - you better tread very lightly, because they will turn on you fast. When coming into the company you negotiate a decent pay rate, but it's hard to get a decent raise on your quarterly review if your'e not a favorite. And same thing goes for the bonuses. This place is just like high school and the property manager is like the big kid on campus; with a group of minions watching their backs and causing havoc whenever they feel it's promitable!

title: Community Manager
pros: I've been with this company for ten years and have had the opportunity to work with the best this industry has to offer. I am proud in the fact that we hire talented individuals, and have a strong training and development department to make them a commodity in this market. We unfortunately lose a lot of these jems that lots of resources are devoted to.
cons: There is a perception of a disconnect between the corporate team and the front lines of the onsite teams. Metric based expectations are unrealistic when the goal of the team on the property is to honestly make it through the day without resident confrontation while adapting to limited budgets and staff reductions. I have honest, hard working, and devoted team members who often feel there is no winning in their role. They honestly care but do not feel rewarded for their efforts due to the lack of dedication from the management from above.

title: Great Company!!!
pros: I really enjoyed my job at Equity! I feel like I grew so much as a leasing consultant and learned so much about the industry. I enjoyed my teammates and the company as a whole. Every time I visited the corporate office I felt welcomed, and was excited to grow with the company. If I hadn't moved to a state where Equity didn't have any properties, I'd definitely still be working for them! - Compensation - Great new hire training - Rent discount - Sense of community with co-workers and other members of the equity team
cons: - Non flexible work schedule - Commission structure compared to the previous management company I worked for - Short staffed

title: leasing
pros: The vacation period you receive after six months
cons: Everything else that is involved in working for Equity Residential.. They are the shadiest company I have ever worked for . You can be recognized as a top producer time and time again , go above and beyond the job description ...on a regular basis and what will you receive for your hard work and help in making Equity thousands of dollars on every apartment you lease or every resident that stays because of you and your teams loyalty to both the resident and the company (one that doesn't deserve it ) ? NONTHING .....well almost nothing , you will receive a 13 cent raise over a three year period ...that's right 13 cents ...true story, that was my experience. Maybe thins have changed , but there are many companies in the field of Property Management ...choose another , this one will scar you for life !

title: Solid Property Management Co
pros: I love the atmosphere here at Equity. It's a company that really does (for the most part) care about their employees. They really do foster a bootstrap mentality that anyone can go from the bottom on up and I see that all the time. They love to promote from within! They also have fantastic online classes and great structure for anyone new to the industry and/or company.
cons: Worst thing? The fact that Equity works with skeletal crews, operating properties super skinny on personal in comparison to other companies. This in turn creates tons of stress as really you could really really use that extra service or office person. The other big con is how they treat employee residents. I have repeatedly seen my rent increases over 10% as an employee and there is literally no way to negotiate without putting up the biggest fuss. It is SO incredibly demotivating to work for a company that you know is taking home millions every year and then the one big perk of property management they squeeze you.

title: Community Manager
pros: Equity is the company I have ever worked for. Equity is so passionate about investing in employees and if you want to move up, the opportunities are there. I’ve worked with the company for 4 years and have been promoted twice already. I started as a Leasing
cons: ultant, new to the industry, was promoted to Leasing Manager and finally Community Manager. Work is work, there are things you will like and dislike about any job but working for Equity gave me additional benefits- a beautiful apartment, that I wouldn’t live in without my discount, and friendships that I’ll never forget. The people who work for this company are the ones who make it and Equity does a great job of bringing them together during classes and leadership summits but also through meet ups outside of work.

title: A horrible company! This is where you literally run and don’t look back!
pros: Absolutely None at this company. The most political and awful leadership I’ve ever dealt with.
cons: I have been doing this for almost 2 decades and I have had quite a few jobs but in all honesty, this one takes the cake on the worst jobs I have ever held. My supervisor was the most unethical, unprofessional, backstabbing, rude and horrible person I’ve ever dealt with and come in contact with in my 4 decades of being alive, and I don’t say this lightly. From slamming papers to talking behind your back and everything in between, is what I dealt with at this Seattle Hi-rise. Their HR to senior leadership is a complete joke. Their 1980 processes is a another issue that I can write a book about. If you are a creative out of the box thinker, this company is not for you. And if you aren’t, have at it!

title: Best Property Management Company
pros: -Competitive Salary -Tiered and competitive commission structure -Good health benefits and matching 401k up to 4% -Great job security and loyalty to employees -10 ways to be a winner: allows challenging opinions and respects yours -400+ communities to choose from in the U.S. -12 different states
cons: -Raises are based on the cost of the employee not the cost of living -Raises are not substantial -Leasing Consultants receive no end of year bonus

title: Bad experience
pros: Good and bad, you may make some friends along the way. The pay is pretty good. If your boss likes you, you can go far in the comapany.
cons: Management pushes their job duties off on you. The stress level is intense, there is no work life balance. Advancement is hard if you are not in the "inner circle". HR doesn't care about you like they say they do. The higher ups don't really know what goes on behind closed doors and they don't care. When numbers look good, it goes without saying "if it ain't broke don't fix it". And metrics are all they care about. Teamwork is a thing of the past. But one can only understand if they try it themselves.

title: Mass Exodus
pros: There is considerable working knowledge within the company about landscaping and how maintenance issues are solved.
cons: The upper management can't jump ship fast enough! There is a heavy exit from the Seattle market, which has always been steady with the hourly staff, and now even salaried staff can't appreciate this company's style. The focus was churning the leasing employees but the odd path to success is not appreciated by everyone. The career kiss of death is to follow their commandment "challenge authority". If you do this, you'll be marked for your Equity career. Egos are fragile and are driving this train 90% of the time. There is a diversity council to steer attention away from the lack of diversity, which is just lip service. The bias against several groups is shocking. Information leaks are famous in this portfolio. The employees actually don't follow any privacy policies because they haven't seen management do this. The average new employee is just out of high school and hasn't experienced real corporate standards anywhere.

title: I wish the experience was better.
pros: • I met some great people. • I learned a lot about property management.
cons: • No work life balance - always working full weekends. • Benefits, specifically the health insurance is terrible and very expensive. • Commission structure doesn’t make sense and is too low. When I asked for clarification about the commission structure, both of my managers were unable to answer my questions. • The training process is absolutely terrible and even when that is shared with the VP and other management, it is ignored and unchanged. • Turn over is insane - great employees are not valued or appreciated until they give their 2 weeks notice. • Although Equity Residential promotes career growth, there is no clear career path for Leasing Consultants and there is no focus on your development. False promises. • Inappropriate and unprofessional management. • Equity Residential claims that they want their employees to speak up and question authority but when employees do, their thoughts and opinions are ignored and employees end up regretting saying anything in the first place.

title: They love to take advantage!
pros: Work Environment is fun, 401K match program, Company events. Property team is very eager to help out each other when needed.
cons: unappreciated, asked to do way more than job description without compensation or promotion, Job demotions for no reason except Company wanting to cut cost but Upper Mangement always talks about how much money Equity makes and how much better they are doing compared to other big companies. Promotion Process is unfair because they for the most part already have someone in place but go through the interview process because they have to. Everyone is paid differently for the same jobs. A new worker with no experience came in making more money than someone who was their 5 years and great at what they did.

title: Wonderful, Fantastic, Overall the Best!
pros: I worked for Equity for 5 years as a property manager and I loved every minute of it! Unfortunately they sold the Lexford Division where I worked; so I ended up working for the new company that bought the Lexford properties. When I first started working for Equity I was amazed at the training that was given, the teamwork, and the open communication with my District Manager. I was not just a number; I was valued! I took over a property that was 70% occupied and had numerous issues with clientele and within 6 months I had it cleaned up and 98% occupied and 100% collected. I did not get just a thank you and a great job; I received a surprise bonus and a thank you gift. My hard work was always rewarded and appreciated. I have never worked for another company that cares so much or that has room for advancement and encourages it. I would recommend Equity Residential to anyone. They are the best out there and you won't regret it!
cons: Honestly there were no downsides to working for them.

title: Work/Life Balance & Mental Health - thing of the past
pros: If you work hard, you will be rewarded. You can easily make property management a life long career - lots of room for growth.
cons: While Equity did a great job during the pandemic, the work/life balance that was provided and the push for mental health awareness has seemed to disappear. Gone are the days in which people have the option to work from home. Many of us had performed and kept the building running while working from home so why now the change? Of course in our industry, being present as a manager is a necessity at times but why not offer WFH 1 - 2 days per week. It seems that Equity is now "back to business" and does not care about mental health any longer. We are still in a pandemic, we still are stressed, we still are not back to "normal life'. Many employees wish that Equity could move forward with the times and revisit schedules, wfh opens, etc. This will entice new employees to apply, engage current employees & increase morale.

title: Phenomenal Company!
pros: Family feel, gorgeous communities, one team, pays well, fantastic benefits package w/ 401K and stock options. I am blessed with the best regional and VP in Nor Cal. Regional team listens to the employees, gets to know them, they feel heard and are treated with respect! When a resident has an issue and goes to corporate, the corporate team actually reaches out to the site and you work on it with them to find resolution. I have NEVER worked for a better company. They truly care and that is hard to find! Every single person is invested and you feel like you are one team which is rare. If you are short staffed, you reach out to another community and they are happy to help. The culture is first class and they reward you and your team for hard work! Fun company events, this year we went to an A's game and they encourage a healthy work-life balance
cons: I cannot think of one con. Equity really treats their employees well!

title: What a place to work at!
pros: I recently hit my year mark at Equity. I worked hard to get to this point and I have been treated well. The training I have received Accelerate for Service has given me the confidence that will lead me into a Service Mange position in the near future. I have been promoted, reviewed and inspected which as giving me more and more respect for this company. The ability to be able to reach out to my co-workers, management and even or VP is amazing. I believe this is the best company to work for! Go team EQR
cons: There are considered in every company. So what most people get all upset about I just receive it, process it, take what information I want to receive from it and move on. But at time we can be a little under staffed. So maybe we can look at staffing at some of our smaller buildings.

title: Good, but room for Improvement
pros: The people. Hands down...the best in the industry. Facilities team is fantastic, even though they are way over stretched. Growth opportunities for those that perform and achieve results. Depending on who you work for you can achieve work-life balance. Generally a positive environment that celebrates diversity and acceptance.
cons: Salaries are low compared to the volume of work. Company runs on lean staffing, and they know it, but they don't compensate their teams for the workload they have to carry. Causing burn out and turnover. Way too many processes to get things approved. CM's have almost no autonomy to make any decisions. The types of things that require VP approval are ridiculous. Therefore the customer service suffers, yet you are held accountable for the metrics and performance with zero influence to affect change.

title: Comfort and Stability During Times of Crisis
pros: During the current COVID crisis, Equity Residential has quickly responded in a way that ensures our residents and employees feel secure and well cared for. While sadly, we hear about so many people in other industries who are losing their jobs, the strong financial position of Equity has allowed employees to continue to work with flexibility, and provided additional paid time off for those who choose to use it. It's a wonderful feeling to know that during times of financial insecurity, we work for a company that will weather any storm. I am proud to work for a company that takes care of its employees and was well prepared to respond to the current crisis in our country. I know I do not have to worry about my own financial or physical well being, as long as I continue to work for EQR.
cons: I've been lucky to be a part of this organization for 20 years- I have no cons to report.

title: It's a large corporation, with all the perks and challenges.
pros: Compensation is fair, especially when you factor in benefits (medical, vacation, 401K match) and other perks. Hourly wage itself may not be as high, but the package as a whole is better than many. Daily satisfaction depends a lot on your direct managers, so it can vary a lot. Overall, you have the opportunity to work with great people and have a stable, reliable career.
cons: As a large, successful corporation, you don't have to worry about going under, but this also means that all decisions are made with consideration for maximum revenue above all else. Policies and procedures dictate everything, which can be comforting but also frustrating in the lack of autonomy. You also have to be ready to relocate to advance, particularly quickly. The competition and drive to be the leader in the industry means that while work/life balance is talked about, those who don't practice it get ahead. Can be a bit of the "old boys club" when in comes to senior leadership.

title: Went downhill during my 10 years in New England
pros: -good work life/balance -fun culture and environment -job has been made simple -pay is good for the level of work you do
cons: -you no longer make any decisions on impact anything. You basically are now just a robot. -hiring decisions have nothing to do with how good you are -recruiting team is not good -no more teamwork among sister properties -RMs went from being great to being awful my last year

title: Equity Has Made Me Confident In My Work
pros: Equity Residential has a great approach to the term "Work/Life Balance". They encourage you to take time off when possible because they recognize that the better employees are treated, the quality of work increases. I have never felt more confident in a job as I do working for Equity. I truly feel like I can grow with this company and reach for positions I never thought possible. Equity thrives on promoting from within and cares a lot about experience and less about an unrelated college degree. Many VP's and Corporate employees have started from the ground up in this company/field. There is a reason why Equity is one of the top Property Mangement companies in the U.S - residents appreciate the passion and drive behind the company which starts with the employees. Equity Residential is a remarkable company!
cons: The employee discount on rent is great, but I do wish that it was a little more in the thriving markets. It is still difficult to afford a lot of the apartments with the discount given.

title: Great Company and Great People
pros: The platforms and programs that Equity has invested in are forward thinking, efficient and add to their value. I do not spend hours running reports to share information with corp personnel. The people I work with are some of the best in the business. Equity encourages their employees to be themselves and senior leaders are very supportive. The pay is fair (not bad/not great). The benefits are great.
cons: Working with a lot of great people makes it a very difficult place to promote. Equity sold many communities in suburban areas which now means to move up, I would also need to move to an urban area. The staffing module is thin. Unfortunately, if someone is out or leaves it is difficult to maintain the same level of service or productivity.

title: Compared to other PM companies, Equity is one of the best companies to work for
pros: I agree with the fair/balanced reviews already written here (you can tell the people with an ax to rind so to speak). Your coworkers really determine your enjoyment and success. All this being said, many of the issues mentioned in these reviews are found in any major corporation regardless of industry. Compared to other Property Management companies I'm familiar with, Equity is by far the best and the only PM company I will work for.
cons: I've worked for the company for over 7 years and there has always been this unspoken "inner circle" you seem to need entrance into in order to be promoted. The company constantly changes its focus, policies and procedures; and there is a continued disconnect between between corporate employees and field employees.

title: Culture is everything
pros: Employees matter. Leaders are accessible. We are heard. Compensation is fair.
cons: I have loved working for Equity but recently there has been a tangible shift in the culture of the company. People are getting scared of the known and there are a lot of hallway conversations happening due to lack of clarity. A lot of turnover at the corporate level with little transparency as to the why so many key leaders are leaving, thus leaving those who stay behind to wonder who is next and more importantly , why are people leaving - especially so many TENURED people.

title: Best job I've ever had
pros: Employees care about the work they do which directly impacts the resident this had a lot to do with the people Equity hires, trains, and compensates. Equity is flexible in ways that allow employees to acquire a happy work-life balance. Most of the properties form tight bonds with their peers which develops a family feeling. This alone is a key ingredient that makes Equity one of the best of the best places to work. Benefits and perks are excellent. Awards and Bonuses.
cons: Recognition is low. Equity tends to award those that boast their victories the most. In other words, if you don't toot your horn you get nothing. Too much business politics.

title: Stuck in a rut
pros: Great benefits, strong company, stable income
cons: Workloads are too heavy for the quality expected, and when you DO go above and beyond you can expect a pat on the back but that's it. I came from a management position out of state and had to take a technician job to get my foot in the door in this economy, (maybe not the best time to relocate), but I really see no way out of my current job. I originally took this position because I need to feed my family and I heard that they are very good about promotions, I have experienced the opposite and I am out looking for a whole new career.....again.

title: This is home.
pros: Supportive management. Higher-ups talk casually and actually get to know their people. Opportunities to move up are common after the first year or two with the company. Many people are eager to help you by allowing you to shadow them at work, teach you what you need for a role you're interested, and coach you. Rental discount is ok but the apartments are great.
cons: Sometimes the company is very set in their old ways. I have spent a lot of energy pushing the company to do things that they should have done years ago, for the sake of the business. However, this year I think they've realized their processes and tools are dusty, so they've started to rollout new programs.

title: Awesome Company! Great team! Exciting opportunities!
pros: Fair compensation, great commission structure, good leadership, lots of room for growth, excellent benefits, good training programs. Seems like there is always something being offered to employees that go above and beyond. Lots of recognition for achievements. Equity has a culture that actually makes me want to get up and go to work.
cons: Inconsistent management practices between different properties; sometimes lazy people get away with a lot. Use of national vendors and not much attention to local vendors who could offer better services at a cheaper price. National vendors know we have deep pockets and cut so many corners that it winds up being more expensive despite the national contract.

title: Service Manager
pros: Support from Management, Able to Question Authority, Diverse leadership and Onsite Teams, Employees are appreciated and there are many ways they can be rewarded on top of their base salary. At other REITS it has felt as if Maintenance/Facilities we're part of the so called untouchables when our Corporate leaders would show up. At Equity it's the exact opposite and was a bit of a shock to me. The fact that our Local Corporate team remembers our onsite staffs name including porters is amazing. I made the right choice moving to Equity. There is a sincere passion for serving people that at other places has been forgotten. The investment in individual development for both service and office staff is ahead of the competition. I'm proud to be a part of an amazing company and will continue to Enjoy The Ride!
cons: No Company Phone, I'm not used to Management being so approachable (if this is even a con)

title: Company treats employees like crap
pros: I don't believe there are any good reasons to work at Equity Residential, except that maybe if you wanted to live on an Equity property, you get a 20% employee discount. After seeing how they run the company however, I would never live on an Equity property.
cons: 1) Can't eat lunch with your co-workers at the same time - everyone has to go at a different time. 2) Manager treats you like slaves - you have to dress nicely to tour apartments and then also get on your hands and knees to clean toilets because maintenance is "too busy". 3) Manager doesn't listen to employee feedback about anything. 4) Compared to other management companies, the leasing consultants here do the jobs of three departments. You have to do deliveries to 200+ apartments, answer all phone calls, perform apartment inspections (which should be maintenance's job), and lease apartments. I was absolutely exhausted working here, I can't believe how I made it through.

title: Great Company - Greater People
pros: There are too many great things to mention when talking about working at Equity Residential. My peers are amazing, incredibly smart and supportive! The benefits are better than I have had anywhere! I especially appreciate knowing this company operates on DOING THE RIGHT THING! There is a lot of focus on employee and resident engagement. Senior leaders are making smart decisions and our company is thriving. Additionally, senior leaders ask for feed back and genuinely listen and take action.
cons: There is a lot of work. However, you are supported and given all the resources you need to complete your responsibilities. Not a lot of opportunity to move into upper management. That is because NO ONE wants to leave! This is a "con" for those wanting to promote to leadership roles but speaks very highly about what this company does to keep it's employees!

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: Field team members are great- I've met some great people. Lots of training and classes. Health insurance is decent and can be pretty low cost but only if you participate in their wellness program.
cons: ultant

title: Regret quitting my job to work here
pros: People are friendly, in a sort of we will smile at you then talk about you later kind of way.
cons: From the outside looking in, it appears this a a great company to work for. In the several months that I've been here, the same company that claims to be diverse and and built on teamwork is anything but. Their motto of "One Team" is a bit of a joke. In the team I work with it's so divided, there is a lack of communication, and the manager clearly favors certain people over others. In addition to try to learn my role I feel like there is always unnecessary drama floating around that make it difficult not only to focus but to want to be engaged in my position. I left a good job, thinking I was coming to a better job and from what I've seen thus far I am hugely disappointed. I hope my opinion changes but I'm doubtful.

title: Loved this place so much - it was very hard to leave
pros: The people who work at Equity make it an amazing place to work. The environment is fun, fast-paced, and challenging. Innovation is a big part of the organizational culture. We love looking for ways to do things better. Employees have a voice and the environment is very open to feedback - you just need to have great intentions, the courage to speak up, and to share your thoughts objectively and with a desire for collaboration and solution in mind.
cons: No major cons to share. Equity is a place where you need to choose to actively engage in all elements of the work to get the most out of the experience.

title: Horrible
pros: If you are the kind of person who takes pride in your job, gives your all because you really enjoy what you do and are not afraid of a challege ... this COULD be the job for you and you may even enjoy it because you are a loyal person.
cons: Management (at least in the region I was in ) is so pompus and self absorbed that it is sickening. You will not be recognized monetarily for your achievements at the end of the year when "bonuses " and pay increases are assigned ...EVEN if you have been regonized as one of the top producers over and over and not only that ,but you will get to be treated inhumanily, You will be told ...you just dont do a good enough job eventhough they have given you awards in paper (not money) that states Excellence in Sales and Customer Service...I my case this coverd the Northwest Region Northern California...sounds important .... think again it gets you 13 cents for three years time oh and you will be lucky to start at $14.00 hr. with twenty years experience.

title: Beware! Company is a Bunch of Frauds
pros: None - this company is not what they proclaim to be. Stay far far away!
cons: Everything - opinion never valued. No say in any decision making. Job transfers unfair as they already have their own plan who they want for position and will complete an interview with you just as a dog and pony show so they could say they were following their internal transfer process. Shady practices going on behind the scenes and with upper management. Tenured employees have been bailing left and right. Equity should now just call themselves Archstone all their employees taking over positions that Equity tenured employees had been waiting for these promotions. Equity doesn't live up to its brand or culture. Consistently lectured on customer service is important and training for customer service. Equity it all falls back on your poor practices by not providing enough staffing to be able to provide customer service and by not allowing us to provide compensations to residents when needed and events.

title: Good Company to work for but getting a little too corporate/cut-throat.
pros: Great properties, coworkers and opportunity because the company is growing so rapidly. I enjoyed working there for 5 years and only left because my husband is military and we were relocating to a place without Equity.
cons: Promotions are more based on who you know than merit. Many unqualified candidates got promoted over qualified ones because of who they went out drinking with after work. Also in the past couple of years the company has become more cut-throat and stopped seeing employees and residents as people due to corporate greed. Everyone is starting to feel like their jobs are not secure and thus looking outside Equity for employment.

title: Company has a high turnover for a reason.
pros: Not bad for a temporary career move. Has excellent training that you can use for another company.
cons: Expectations are unrealistic. You easily get burned out. Upper management views you as being replaceable. Hard for minorities to make it to the top, but very easy to get hired for entry level positions. I could go on forever and tell you how Equity loss sight of employee engagement and how so many people hate it.

title: Amazing Employer!
pros: The culture at Equity Residential is employee centered and embraces diversity. It is always a preference to promote from within and support employees in achieving their career goals. It is not unusual to meet co-workers that have been with Equity for 15 years+. Equity is a company that encourages us to “question authority” and listens to new ideas. I have built strong relationships at Equity and feel valued as a team member in the almost 10 years I have been with Equity.
cons: There are staffing challenges for both the office and service teams for some communities that operate in high volume environments or incur seasonal increases in traffic volume. However, this wouldn’t apply to all sites and Equity has taken great strides to offer floating and transitional roles to help assist on-site teams.

title: Community Manager
pros: - Great opportunities for advancement. I worked at Equity for 3 and a half years and was promoted several times. They recognize hard work and motivate you to accomplish your goals - Great people. I just left EQR and really miss working with some of the best people in the business - They use some of the best software that really help organize your day and manage your community -Ops, MRI, Google, etc.
cons: - Huge staffing/turnover issues. They under staff their properties and expect a lot from the property level (especially with maintenance). - Increase operating budgets - Allow more input from property level. All vendor contract negotiation is on corporate level - Everything is micro managed and needs VP approval - Salary is not very competitive with market - Culture was great when I first started- many outings, happy hours, and ways to meet co workers. They don't do this much anymore. There is definitely a lack of comradery and employee engagement

title: Opportunities, Growth and Support From Leadership!
pros: I started with Equity as a Leasing
cons: ultant, was promoted to Senior Leasing Consultant, then promoted to Assistant Manager and now Community Manager. My experience with Equity has been one of constant support and encouragement toward growth and furthering my career and personal development. Equity frequently rewards exceptional effort and results with awards and bonuses. Pay is competitive. Larger company, which means more opportunities for advancement, more often. Equity is ethical and has created a culture of kindness around "doing the right thing."

title: Great onsite team
pros: At both downtown properties, I loved my colleagues and managers. Managers were professional - nice, considerate, and stood up for their employees in cases when residents cross the line. I got to plan events during the slower times and that ended up launching my current career.
cons: - Working late and very early hours for a building without a security guard was uncomfortable as a young woman. - Disconnect with HQ. When HQ people came to visit, they didn't even bother to meet the staff. Also when they wanted to remodel the lobby space, they didn't bother to ask for input by the staff. It makes no sense to separate the package room from the reception desk. - They started letting go of managers.

title: A wonderful place to work with amazing people
pros: The teams! Everyone I have worked with has been super kind and supportive. I would not have stayed with the company as long as I have if it weren't for the amazing team I work with. I also genuinely feel like my General and Regional Managers care about me and my team. The hourly compensation is pretty competitive, and the rent discount is good too. The benefits are also the best I have seen at any of the places I have worked. The company clearly cares about the sales and statistics, but you won't have to worry about losing your job if you have a slow month and don't meet your quota. I highly recommend considering working for Equity Residential, and I have recommended EQR to my friends in the past as well.
cons: The commissions could be better. The commissions are pretty low compared to other companies.

title: Great Culture...Poor Senior Management
pros: EQR hires great people who fit the "10 way" culture. People are fun to work with and EQR encourages team work. EQR is great at hiring people who love what they do and want to make a difference to the residents. If you have a great manager - your life will be much easier and you will enjoy working there. Great apt discount.
cons: Large disconnect between HQ in Chicago and regional offices. Seems HQ (2N) does not truly understand how the changes they consistently implement can reflect so much pressure on lower level employees. Like most large companies, money is giving to senior level employees while the leasing/service teams make little next to nothing even though they bring in the revenue. Pressure to promote too fast therefore unqualified managers in roles. Internal promotion system is not fair to all employees.

title: A little behind the times
pros: The office primarily uses Google Suite which was amazing! WFO, office optional. Very laid back. Low work load. Month end was typically easy.
cons: The company only cares about the bottom line and not its tenants. Most employee's cannot afford to live in the apartments they manage, not even with the company discount. Health insurance REQUIRES everyone on the plan to exercise (even non-employee members i.e. spouse) and report workouts in order to lower your health insurance bills. The company save money the more all colleagues report workouts, and weight-loss. Although the actual reporting is private it still seems a bit invasive. Either give this discount or don't, but requiring all insurees's household to follow a fitness plan is intrusive.

title: Not worth the effort
pros: great benefits stock options discounts with vendors software advancements
cons: Your raise every year is predetermined and not negotiable, your commissions are sometimes discretionary- not every manager pays out every commission. Some former employees were terminated with one story and then told unemployment offices a different story. Property or regional/area managers can prevent you from changing properties or applying for promotions. If you live at an Equity Property and get terminated, you have 7 days to move out.

title: Excellent core values, hard work to trickle down to properties, excellent career experience, the best matrix system.
pros: Pay for performance, diversity, allowed to function as your own business
cons: Hours needed (not required by the company) to be the best are far too demanding to have any work - life balance, even with all the company programs to promote balance.

title: More than a dusty set of values...
pros: I chose to work for a company that fit my values, perspectives, responsibilities, and overall development culture of both my own private business ventures, but also the experiences of other employers. The '10 ways' are certainly these. They aren't just some value system that is hung on a wall and forgotten. They are lived and breathed each day, in every way possible.
cons: Honestly, I've been working for EQR for a while, and can't think of anything, other than there aren't many properties on the INTERIOR/Middle of the US, as they own most large growing markets in metro's near coasts!

title: Great job when times are good. A struggle when it's bad.
pros: Great benefits. Many great people to work with. Rent discounts. Transfer opportunities.
cons: Room for advancement/change is not easy to do although they promote that it is. Procedures and policies prevent people from being promoted (or even allowed to apply) such as time in job or your managers opinion. Often employees are told that can't or shouldn't be considered for a job because they have not been in their position long enough even if they are more than qualified. Exceptions are made for some but not all employees. If you get your foot in at the right time and play the game right, you can do great.

title: Equity Residential values YOU!
pros: Equity Residential (EQR) is an emotionally intelligent organization that understands the value of work-life balance. They encourage it and they practice it from the top down. From the moment I walked in the door I was provided with the tools that not only assisted me in being a better employee but also in being a better mother, daughter and wife. The mission, vision and strategy of Equity Residential resides in the spirit of every employee... I will never forget the lessons I learned there.
cons: No cons unless you are a part of a portfolio that is sold. The only con I can truly think of is the amount of travel for certain departments. Leadership outside of the Chicago office can sometimes be counter "EQR" culture but for the most part everyone is on board with the mission, vision and strategy of EQR as a whole.

title: Great place to work
pros: Great benefits. Well run company from a financial standpoint. Senior mgmt (CEO, CFO, COO) are the best in the industry. Company allows you to work virtually when you wish. Central location in West Loop near Ogilvie and Union Stations. 5 minute walk to Blue Line. Fun monthly get togethers like group breakfast, afternoon snack breaks.
cons: Company is spread out over 3 floors - you can go several days without seeing people from different departments unless you make a point of it. Makes networking more difficult and "being visible".

title: Leasing consultant
pros: I truly admire the culture of equity. They offer competitive pay and benefits are great!
cons: - CM’s do whatever they want. My current CM takes a 4 hour lunch every single day without fail (12-4) and when he returns, he locks himself in his office for the remainder of the day and works on his college class work. Doesn’t answer phones, doesn’t speak to resident or return their requested call backs. Doesn’t make himself present and our resident always make it a point to comment how the CM is never around or locked behind closed doors. - staffing. You will always hear “we run lean”. I get the reason behind it but in exchange, you will feel ran to the ground by the end of each day. Expectations are extremely high.

title: Look no further than Equity Residential
pros: Outstanding support system for new and current employees, healthy home/work life balance, and a culture that invites new and fresh ideas without fear of losing your job or for speaking up on what you feel may be the right thing to do. EQR is with the times and they try to streamline everything to make your job easier. I love that I can easily communicate with all of our residents via email, I love that we have upscale events for our residents, and just overall appreciate the support that has been given to me as a new manager to the company.
cons: I have been an employee for about 6 months now and no cons that I can think of. I've been in the industry for about 10 years now and this is the happiest I have been and I feel like I can truly be myself.

title: Best company in the industry!
